trans-unit.source: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.
trans-unit.target: In XAML markup, specifies a null value for a property.

trans-unit.source: xNull markup extension
trans-unit.target: xNull markup extension

trans-unit.source: {x:Null} markup extension
trans-unit.target: {x:Null} markup extension

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: In XAML markup, specifies a **null** value for a property.
trans-unit.target: In XAML markup, specifies a **null** value for a property.

trans-unit.source: XAML attribute usage
trans-unit.target: XAML attribute usage

trans-unit.source: Remarks
trans-unit.target: Remarks

trans-unit.source: **null** is the null reference keyword for C# and C++.
trans-unit.target: **null** is the null reference keyword for C# and C++.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Visual Basic keyword for a null reference is **Nothing**.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Visual Basic keyword for a null reference is **Nothing**.

trans-unit.source: The initial default value can vary between dependency properties, and it is not necessarily **null**.
trans-unit.target: The initial default value can vary between dependency properties, and it is not necessarily **null**.

trans-unit.source: Further, many dependency properties will not accept **null** as a value (whether through markup or code) due to their internal implementation.
trans-unit.target: Further, many dependency properties will not accept **null** as a value (whether through markup or code) due to their internal implementation.

trans-unit.source: In such cases, setting a XAML attribute value with **{x:Null}** can result in a parser exception.
trans-unit.target: In such cases, setting a XAML attribute value with **{x:Null}** can result in a parser exception.

trans-unit.source: Some Windows Runtime types are nullable.
trans-unit.target: Some Windows Runtime types are nullable.

trans-unit.source: In cases where a nullable type does not already have **null** as the default, you could use **{x:Null}** in XAML to set to the **null** value.
trans-unit.target: In cases where a nullable type does not already have **null** as the default, you could use **{x:Null}** in XAML to set to the **null** value.

trans-unit.source: If using Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), nullable types are represented as [**Platform::IBox<T>**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/jj606120.aspx).
trans-unit.target: If using Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), nullable types are represented as [**Platform::IBox<T>**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/jj606120.aspx).

trans-unit.source: If using Microsoft .NET languages, nullable types are represented as [**Nullable<T>**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/b3h38hb0.aspx).
trans-unit.target: If using Microsoft .NET languages, nullable types are represented as [**Nullable<T>**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/b3h38hb0.aspx).
